author: Thei Zervaki
title: New Orleans, 10 Years Later
text:
reddit 
I visited New Orleans twice this summer. Although the purpose of my trips were more business than leisure I found time to stroll around the city that 10 years ago was partially destroyed by a massive hurricane. My camera captured better than my words how the city is and feels today. Here are some shots of the Crescent City that we all love to visit. 
The day starts with a long line at the historic Cafe du Monde. Locals go very early in the morning -- I was told -- to avoid those lines and so I did as well 
Employees at the Cafe du Monde are taking a break 
Enjoying a cafe au lait with beignets at the Cafe du Monde 
At the trendy Magazine street that extends from the Garden District to the Warehouse District areas there are several boutiques and cafes that both locals and travelers visit. Here locals relax at the Stein's Market and Deli 
On the streetcar back to the French Quarter 
Visiting the French Market is an experience as it is one of the oldest public markets in the country 
The famous muffuletta at the Central Grocery and Deli 
Little boys are running (and dancing) happily on the street 
Later in the evening, musicians share their music in public on the streets of French Quarter 
And I am having the French 75 at Arnaud's with some of the guests 
Life seems to be fine in New Orleans. As a local told me "it is fine but not the same." The sunset says it all though.
